original_context: Punk is not active at night.
If Punk climbs trees or runs fast, then he can escape predators.
All carnivorous animals hunt preys and eat meat.
If Punk either has claws or has fur (but not both), then he is a carnivore.
If an animal has fur, then it either likes shade or likes water, but not both.
Punk either lives in a forest or likes shade.
If Punk lives in a forest and has large eyes, then he is active at night.
If Punk navigates in the dark or climbs trees, then he can find food.
If Punk lives at night, then he is secretive.
If Punk has excellent hearing, then he either lives at night or navigates in the dark.
conclusion: If Punk is nocturnal, then he either has large eyes or has excellent hearing, but not both.

google/gemini-2.5-pro-preview.mistake: The natural language statement "If an animal has fur, then it either likes shade or likes water, but not both" is a general statement, implying universal quantification (i.e., it applies to any animal). The corresponding FOL statement provided is "p_17(Punk) → (p_16(Punk) ⊕ p_4(Punk))", which is a specific statement about the individual 'Punk'. While this could be an instance of the general rule for Punk (assuming Punk is an animal), it is not a direct translation of the general rule itself. A direct FOL translation of the NL statement would be universally quantified, for example: ∀x (Animal(x) ∧ p_17(x) → (p_16(x) ⊕ p_4(x))), or if the domain is implicitly animals, ∀x (p_17(x) → (p_16(x) ⊕ p_4(x))).

openai/gpt-4.1.mistake: None. All FOL statements correctly match the natural language.

openai/o4-mini-high.mistake: 1. Used ¬is_p_1 instead of ¬p_1 for “not active at night.” 2. Used inclusive ∨ for “either … or” in p_14∨p_16 when NL implies exclusive or. 3. In (p_14∧p_15)→is_p_1 they mistakenly used predicate is_p_1 instead of p_1.

google/gemini-2.5-pro-preview.mistake:
One of the pairs shows an incorrect mapping. Specifically, the pair:
NL: If an animal has fur, then it either likes shade or likes water, but not both.
FOL: p_17(Punk) → (p_16(Punk) ⊕ p_4(Punk))
The natural language statement describes a general rule applicable to any animal ('an animal'). This typically translates to a universally quantified statement in FOL (e.g., ∀x (Animal(x) ∧ p_17(x) → (p_16(x) ⊕ p_4(x))) if p_17(x) means 'x has fur'). The provided FOL statement, however, is a specific assertion about the individual 'Punk'. A specific assertion about an individual is not a correct translation of a general rule, even if Punk is an animal. The FOL is about Punk; the NL is about animals in general.

openai/gpt-4.1.mistake: None; all FOL-NL mappings are correct and make sense.
